reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Giving me Historical Mr. and Mrs. Smith vibes
reviews.reviewText: POV: DualSpice: 🌶 🌶 🌶This book is a wild, romantic and suspenseful ride that I couldn’t put down! It didn’t just take place in England, instead it starts on a ship mid Atlantic from England to Civil War era America, then to France, and back to England. Bronwyn and Valentine are like a historical Mr. and Mrs. Smith and I am here for it!While I admit to wanting to knock some sense into both of the characters a few times, I loved both of them! Amalie Howard always does a strong and independent Lady and broody Duke so well and this book was no different! I feel like a lot of historical romances are slow burn but this one was a little faster and I’m so thankful it was because their chemistry was obvious from the first page.There are definitely some interesting side characters that I hope get their stories, but I have no idea who it could possibly be so I will be waiting on the edge of my seat to find out, because I absolutely love this series!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I read all 3 books in this series and I have to admit I liked this one the most. It had intrigue, spying and Ms. Howard kept me guessing until the end who was responsible for trying to kill Bronwyn. Cyndi

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A starchy duke meets his match…
reviews.reviewText: One of my favorite reads of 2022 was Amalie Howard’s newest release, The Duke in Question.Here are just a few of the reasons you need to pick it up:1. A starchy duke who cannot hang onto his cool to save his life where the heroine is concerned. She’s sheer kamikaze to his self-control.2. Innuendoes and banter that will make your head spin with their crackling intensity and barely masked antagonism.3. A fiercely independent heroine who refuses to let the restrictions society places on her gender deter her from pursuing what she wants.4. Some of my favorite mini-tropes… including bathtime teasing, and hot times against a tree.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Interesting read - but too "contemporary" for me
reviews.reviewText: Lady Bronwyn Chase, the half-sister of Courtland Chase, the Duke of Ashvale, didn’t intentionally set out to be a spy, rather she stumbled into espionage. But once she had a taste, she was hooked and began working for an agent of the crown, just passing on the occasional message, but it soon became apparent that she was actually good at it and the “Kestrel” was born and caught the interest of other agents, particularly Valentine Medford, the new Duke of Thornbury, a retired agent who is helping his former partner track the Kestrel. Which is how they all end up on a ship bound for Philadelphia in March of 1865.Bronwyn plays her part as a shallow, self-absorbed debutante to perfection and annoys Thornbury to no end. Bronwyn has long had a crush on Thornbury, but he is one of her brother’s best friends and until recently, married, so he is off-limits – or is he? She reminds herself that she has a mission and can’t waste time mooning over a man who could never love her and one who is too smart to fool for long with her foolish society girl facade, so she tries to avoid him and focus on her mission.Valentine doesn’t know that she is the Kestrel, but isn’t happy about her traipsing about Philadelphia alone and wonders what she is up to. He follows her and is stunned to see what she is up to. And when her mission goes awry and her life is on the line, he wastes no time saving her. But when she turns the tables and saves him, twice – everything changes and he finds himself torn between duty and desire.This was a very interesting read and I am torn about how to rate this – as far as writing, plot, and character development are concerned, the book is spot on with lots of action, steamy love scenes, interesting characters, true historical events tie-ins, and a HEA, but it is supposed to be a “historical romance” set in the very uptight Victoria Era and that is where it doesn’t work for me. The characters have very progressive, modern views on sex, relationships, and equality, that came across as very cavalier, making this more of a “contemporary in period dress” than a true to the era historical. Then there were things that just shook me – the hero is “divorced” which is almost unheard of in the Victorian era and would take years to accomplish as well as an act of Parliament and a lot of money, not to mention a better reason than “we wanted different things”, but they apparently got it done quickly and quietly and he and his ex are still friends and everyone seems to think this is no big deal as they are not shunned and are still accepted everywhere – but then it is implied that they were not really married, even though the ex still uses the title that she had as his “wife”, but the hero never tells the heroine any of this, which bothered me probably more than it should have. And don’t even get me started on the virgin heroine’s attitude toward sex. I understand that authors are trying to appeal to a 21st-century audience and the popularity of shows like Bridgerton has brought a host of new readers who are not familiar with the rules and strictures of the eras and would be put off by them – so there has to be some leeway – but I feel that this one went too far – I read historicals for those strictures and rules and how different times were – making characters “too modern” ruins that for me and honestly by implying that the views of the day were the same as they are now, diminishes the challenges and hardships people in that time overcame and in some cases are still overcoming. But that is just my personal opinion and if adherence to historical protocols isn’t a big deal for you – I am sure you will really enjoy this story. This is the third book in the series, but it could easily be read and enjoyed as a standalone title.*I am voluntarily leaving a review for an eARC that I requested and was provided to me by the publisher. All opinions in this review are my own.*

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2022
reviews.reviewText: I liked the characters chemistry and the story. Was a little slow to start but I enjoyed it. Would recommend.

reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars exciting with great love scenes
reviews.reviewText: I really enjoyed the characters in this book. The story was interesting too with it being located partly in America.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2023
reviews.reviewText: The story was a bit slow at the start but grew on my interest! I'm glad I kept reading as I could not stop reading until the end!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I really enjoyed this book, and am racing to go back and read the previous books in this series. I loved that this book took place partly on a ship, and the spy aspect was so different and unique! Ms. Howard is definitely a new favorite author!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 22, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Thoroughly enjoyed this story. Looking forward to the next one.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 13, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: Loved this book, love this author
reviews.reviewText: I wish there was another in this series coming out tomorrow, of the three, this was my favourite and tbh, I might have fallen a little bit in love with Valentine

reviews.reviewTitle: Maybe it improves in the last half!
reviews.reviewText: I got about a third of the way through before the growing list of historical absurdities and the ridiculousness of the characters in this book led me to start skimming, and finally just gave up on it entirely about halfway in. Maybe if it were a cheap ebook I wouldn't have been so hard on it, and maybe it improves further on but, right now, I'd have to say that this was the book I most regret buying in paperback form in 2022.
